subNodes.conversationText: root

<FirstName> came upon a protected alcove in the mountainside too shallow to be called a cave. Someone had cleared the stones away near the entrance and tried -- with little success -- to establish a vegetable garden in their place. A few dwarfed ears of corn sat nearby for shucking.
"Hello?" called <FirstName>.
There was no one home.
<FirstName> moved on.
A bearded man peered out, squinting in the sunlight. He was dressed in rags and had a huge mane of gray hair. No mountain hermit could be more hermit-like, <FirstName> thought.
[Continue.]
"You're bold to climb the mountain with the Congress of Moths at large. What brings you here?" His voice and accent were urbane, at odds with his appearance.
"I'm looking for a murderer, a hunter who lives in the woods."
"I've killed -- but that was a long time ago. I'm not a hunter either. I don't eat meat except for the fish I catch in the streams. Besides -- the woods are below. This is the mountain."
[Continue.]
"Leave me. I choose to live in solitude for a reason."
"You can have your solitude back soon. I just wanted to talk."
<FirstName> had read enough to know that hermits' loquacity was easily encouraged.
[Continue.]

"I suppose I could tell you something of myself, if you'd hear it. It needs rehearsing. Old people need to stretch their legs once in a while, or they'll start forgetting things, and a tale needs to be told, or it'll be forgotten."
[Continue.]
"Please, have a seat," he said. He sat down on a round boulder near the entrance to his home and gestured to another.
"I'll stand."
"Suit yourself."
[Continue.]
"A warning -- my story is quite long. Do you truly want to hear it?"
"Yes."
"And I must ask -- did anyone put you up to this?"
"Why would anyone do that?"
This satisfied him, and he began his tale. This is what he said.
[Continue.]

"I came into power at a young age. My uncle was the elected leader of a great city-state -- I will not tell you which -- only that it is very far from here. Before he died, he schemed to give me his seat. I knew what he was doing and felt no shame. Why should I? I believed I was entitled to all that I had -- and more."
"Your uncle had no children of his own?"
"No. He hardly knew me, but it was enough that we shared a name. My mother had been his favorite sister -- that was all it was. Certainly no virtue of my own."
[Continue.]

"I was a bad leader. I gave my friends the best posts and did terrible things to my enemies. I wrung fat from the city's rich and marrow from the city's poor. Despite the hate my deeds earned me, I felt utterly secure in my position. I had no notion that my injustices might undo me."
"Interesting. Go on."

"I was a bad leader. I gave my friends the best posts and did terrible things to my enemies. I wrung fat from the city's rich and marrow from the city's poor. Despite the hate my deeds earned me, I felt utterly secure in my position. I had no notion that my injustices might undo me."
"You were forced out of power, I take it."
"Yes."
[Continue.]

"It was my fifth year in office. There was a generations-long feud between my family and another, the Megaei. When my abuses made me unpopular, they rallied the people and the military and the -- peculiar institutions of the city against me."
"Peculiar institutions?"
The old man looked hard at the young witch. Then he shook his head. "Oh, why hide it? I refer to the Geometrium. I once ruled Jad Bizunta."
"Are you a magician?"
"Not everyone who lives in Jad Bizunta is a magician. Most aren't. I know nothing of the 77 tiers."
[Continue.]

"Anyway, dissidents blocked me in my mansion. There was no way to leave. I went to my window once, hoping to inspire loyalty. I don't know what feeble words I would have attempted, because I never had the chance. The crowd threw rocks. One struck my face. I fled the room; the next day, I was deposed, and I surrendered the government to the scion of the Megaei."
"I see. And then you repented and became a hermit?"
"Ha! No, no, not at all. The coup was 20 years ago. It was only the beginning."
[Continue.]

"The Megaei should have had me killed, but not all my family was as contemptible as I was, and few were powerless. Hylo Megae, the new leader of the city, exiled me instead."

"At first, I was helpless and nearly starved. But the thought of revenge was food and drink to me, and it kept me alive, more vampire than man. Sometimes I imagined making a massacre in my enemies' house; sometimes I thought I'd kill them one by one, whispering my grievances as they bled out. I heard the fanfare of trumpets as I climbed over their corpses to retake my seat."
"Spite's dreams can be vivid," remarked the young witch.
"Indeed."
[Continue.]

"Meanwhile, Hylo Megae had not found it easy to govern. In trying to please everybody, he pleased nobody. He cultivated an appearance of selflessness and generosity, but it meant little to the people -- who, when they are unhappy, see vice but overlook virtue. He was becoming as unpopular as I'd been, and he feared the same fate or worse. Remembering the blockade of the mansion and mistrusting the military, he hired mercenaries to guard it."
[Continue.]

"I was among those mercenaries, disguised, unknown, forgotten. Desperation and vengeance had hardened what was soft in me and sharpened what was cruel. When the discontents gathered outside the mansion once again, I convinced the company to turn on our employer. I had the satisfaction of gutting him in his bed."
"What a reversal!" said the young witch.
"It was too perfect," he agreed. "I didn't accomplish it all by myself."
[Continue.]

"Over the years, my family had suggested that my abuses were fictions perpetuated by the Megaei, that I had been the victim of political intrigue. In their version of things, my only fault had been idealistic naivete. Not everyone believed this, but enough did that the story had more power than memory or fact."

"When word got out that the grim warrior who killed Hylo Megae was the hero of that story, the people were thrilled. They swept me up onto the pedestal of popular acclaim and then onward, into my old position."
"Your second chance in government. Did you make the most of it?"
"Ha! That could mean too many things. I made more of it, but not much more."
[Continue.]

"The first thing was to execute Hylo's immediate family -- all save a daughter who escaped. I banished the rest."

"And then I led the city for thirteen years. After the thrill of regaining my power, I found government boring. I tried. I did. I tried to be interested in it, even grateful to the citizens who had rallied to me. Then I tried, a little, to go back to my dissolute ways. But the food tasted bitter, and the love tasted hollow, and the wine, I knew, was perilous."
"How did it end?"

"I was a better leader than I had been, but that's not saying much. When I faced crises, I retreated. When one faction or another tried to take advantage of me, I usually let them. I had no doctrine or philosophical convictions. I tired of everything, and when I lost my third election, I banished myself to this mountaintop, far away from everything I'd known, because the life here seemed clearer and better."
"You have quite a story."
"Yes. The story is behind me, and now there's just living." He took a deep breath of the mountain air.
[Continue.}
"You had power to do good, and you squandered it."
"I had no will to do good. I left the city in better hands>"
[Continue.}
"I do not regret leaving."
[Continue.]
"I am here, breathing and eating and thinking -- and talking, sometimes."
[Continue.]
"It is life."
"You had the power to do what you wanted, and you squandered it."
"But that's just it -- I didn't want anything."
[Continue.}
"And is life here clearer and better?"
"It is life."
"Thank you for your story."
"Of course. I never got your name, young witch."
"<FirstName>."
"A pleasure. I am Zaurus."
"I know."
<FirstName> nodded. <He/She> had thought as much.
"Let's keep it that way. Names can be dangerous."
<FirstName> nodded.
"I suppose you'll be on your way, then. It occurs to me -- I never got your name."
"<FirstName>."
"Let's keep it that way. Names can be dangerous."
The young witch waited for the conclusion.

"I was a better leader than I had been, but that's not saying much. When I faced crises, I retreated. When one faction or another tried to take advantage of me, I usually let them. I had no doctrine or philosophical convictions. I tired of everything, and when I lost my third election, I banished myself to this mountaintop, far away from everything I'd known, because the life here seemed clearer and better."
"Well, I've heard most of it, I imagine. I should be off now, though."
The hermit scowled. "Go on then."
<FirstName> nodded, wondering what happened next.

"The first thing was to execute Hylo's immediate family -- all save a daughter who escaped. I banished the rest."

"And then I led the city for thirteen years. After the thrill of regaining my power, I found government boring. I tried. I did. I tried to be interested in it, even grateful to the citizens who had rallied to me. Then I tried, a little, to go back to my dissolute ways. But the food tasted bitter, and the love tasted hollow, and the wine, I knew, was perilous."
"A fascinating story, but I must be off," said <FirstName>.
"And then, satisfied, you retired to these mountains?"
"You are impatient! No. It would have been better if I had. But no. I owed it to my family to see the plot through even after I'd accomplished my vengeance."
[Continue.]

"Over the years, my family had suggested that my abuses were fictions perpetuated by the Megaei, that I had been the victim of political intrigue. In their version of things, my only fault had been idealistic naivete. Not everyone believed this, but enough did that the story had more power than memory or fact."

"When word got out that the grim warrior who killed Hylo Megae was the hero of that story, the people were thrilled. They swept me up onto the pedestal of popular acclaim and then onward, into my old position."
"A fascinating story, but I must be off," said <FirstName>.
The hermit scowled. "Go on then."
"Go on."

"Meanwhile, Hylo Megae had not found it easy to govern. In trying to please everybody, he pleased nobody. He cultivated an appearance of selflessness and generosity, but it meant little to the people -- who, when they are unhappy, see vice but overlook virtue. He was becoming as unpopular as I'd been, and he feared the same fate or worse. Remembering the blockade of the mansion and mistrusting the military, he hired mercenaries to guard it."
But now <FirstName> had heard enough. <He/She> excused <him/her>self.
The hermit scowled. "Go on then."
<FirstName> gestured for the man to continue.

"The Megaei should have had me killed, but not all my family was as contemptible as I was, and few were powerless. Hylo Megae, the new leader of the city, exiled me instead."

"At first, I was helpless and nearly starved. But the thought of revenge was food and drink to me, and it kept me alive, more vampire than man. Sometimes I imagined making a massacre in my enemies' house; sometimes I thought I'd kill them one by one, whispering my grievances as they bled out. I heard the fanfare of trumpets as I climbed over their corpses to retake my seat."
<FirstName> had grown impatient. <He/She> excused <him/her>self.
"Fascinating. Well, what happened next?"

"Anyway, dissidents blocked me in my mansion. There was no way to leave. I went to my window once, hoping to inspire loyalty. I don't know what feeble words I would have attempted, because I never had the chance. The crowd threw rocks. One struck my face. I fled the room; the next day, I was deposed, and I surrendered the government to the scion of the Megaei."
The revelation wasn't enough to sustain <FirstName>'s interest. <He/She excused <him/her>self.
The hermit scowled. "Go on then."
It was a curious omission, but <FirstName> didn't pry.

As it turned out, <he/she> didn't need to.

"Oh, what can it matter?" the hermit said after a moment. "I refer to the Geometrium. I once ruled Jad Bizunta. "
"Are you a magician?"
"Fascinating. Well, what happened next?"
The revelation wasn't enough to sustain <FirstName>'s interest. <He/She excused <him/her>self.
<FirstName> had grown impatient. <He/She> excused <him/her>self.
The hermit scowled. "Go on then."
"Go on."
"You can probably guess how this part of my story ends."
[Continue.]
<FirstName> was already growing impatient. <He/She> excused <him/her>self.
<FirstName> was already growing impatient. <He/She> excused <him/her>self.
The hermit scowled. "Go on then."
[End.]
THE HERMIT.

"I came into power at a young age. My uncle was the elected leader of a great city-state -- I will not tell you which -- only that it is very far from here. Before he died, he schemed to give me his seat. I knew what he was doing and felt no shame. Why should I? I believed I was entitled to all that I had -- and more."
"No. Until I saw you, I never knew of your existence."
This satisfied him, and he began his tale. This is what he said.
"I have only myself to thank for the opportunity."
This satisfied him, and he began his tale. This is what he said.
"I'll let you know if I have to go."
"So be it."
[Continued.]
"And I must ask -- did anyone put you up to this?"
"I'm afraid I don't have time for stories, actually."
<FirstName> complied and found another boulder to sit on.
"A warning -- my story is quite long. Do you truly want to hear it?"
"I'm afraid I don't have time for stories, actually."
The hermit looked disappointed. "Go on, then," he said gruffly, waving the witch away.
"What reason is that?"
<FirstName> had read enough to know that hermits' loquacity was easily encouraged.
"Very well."
"Yes yes, off with you," he said -- though he didn't retreat back into his alcove.
"It's been too long since I ran into somebody in my travels. Are you sure you don't want to chat?"
<FirstName> had read enough to know that hermits' loquacity was easily encouraged.
<FirstName> continued up the mountain.
"I seek the kami who dwells in these mountains."

"I can't help you with that. I've sometimes heard the wind carrying a deep, terrifying voice, and when night is black and there's no moon I've felt the ground shake, as if some enormous thing were bestriding the mountain. There's no question this place is haunted -- but where the spirit treads I can't tell you."
[Continue.]
"Leave me. I choose to live in solitude for a reason."
"No reason. I'm an explorer."
"An explorer who also practices witchcraft, I suppose," said the hermit. Pharaoh was preening himself on <FirstName>'s shoulder.
"You suppose well."
"Leave me. I choose to live in solitude for a reason."
<FirstName> shrugged.
"Leave me. I choose to live in solitude for a reason."
"Yes, so you'd better deal honestly with me."
"Leave me. I choose to live in solitude for a reason."
<FirstName> moved on.
